text:
ROB MANFRED: Well, we were
thrilled with the tournament.

You know, I had an opportunity
to see games in Seoul,
in Tokyo, in Miami, and LA.

We had great attendance, great
atmosphere in the ballpark.

And really exciting opportunity
to showcase our young players
around the world.

KATE RILEY: The global
growth of the game

is clearly of very
high importance,

and were not just games at
the World Baseball Classic

being held overseas,
but games in general

being held in popular baseball
strongholds such as Cuba,
Australia, and Japan.
So where is next and why?

ROB MANFRED: Well,
I think that we're

going to continue to focus
on places where baseball is
part of the culture.

Mexico is very high
on our priority list.

We want to play regular
season games in Mexico.

We're working towards
that goal with respect
to the 2018 season.

There are also other
parts of Latin America
that we need to get back to.

Puerto Rico is very high
on that list as well.

KATE RILEY: Right,
speaking here as a Brit,

so do you envisage
baseball ever going

down the road of
having a franchise
outside of North America?

You've even said that quote,
"in reality, New York to London

is not that much further than
New York to the West Coast."

ROB MANFRED: Well, we're
very interested in London
as a gateway to Europe.

We'd like to get regular
season games played in London,
just a series to begin with.

But I do believe that as
travel continues to evolve,

that London would
be a possibility
for us over the long haul.

KATE RILEY: Now regardless
of global growth,

the majority of your
focus on your sport

must still be based around
the upcoming season.

We were all captivated
by the Chicago Cubs

winning that elusive World
Series after a 108 year wait.

Before we turn to this
season, presumably

even the commissioner
of baseball

must have been swept up in what
was the Cubs amazing story.

ROB MANFRED: Well,
I've been going
to World Series for 25 years.

I always find the World Series
to be compelling programming.

But I must admit, the 2016
addition was really special.

The Cubs with their 108 year
drought, great storyline.

But you know, Cleveland was
a great storyline as well.

68 years is a long time
without a championship.

So hopefully we'll
find those same kind
of storylines in 2017.
KATE RILEY: Yeah, we hope so.

Now I understand that when you
became the 10th commissioner

in baseball history,
one of your priorities

was to captivate the next
generation of sports fans

in a way that you yourself were
captivated when your parents

took you to the Yankee Stadium
for the first time back in 1968

and where you saw
the great Mickey
Mantle hit two home runs.

Do you think you've
managed to captivate
the current generation?

ROB MANFRED: Well, we think
we're making great progress
with the next generation.

There's really three
parts to our initiative.

Number one, we think
it's important for kids
to play the game.

And our Play Ball initiative
is really working at the grass

roots to make sure
that kids are playing
baseball in large numbers.

It remains the most
played sport for children
under the age of 18.

And our participation numbers
are actually increasing.

Secondly, our clubs
do a great job

about encouraging families
to come to the ballpark,

to bring their kids
to the ballpark.

Because the earlier they go to
the ballpark, the more likely

it is that they
remain fans for life.

And then of course, the
third piece is technology.

Our At Bat application
has attracted
a very young audience.

Average user is about
30 years of age.

And we feel that
technology is the key

to keeping the next generation
engaged with the great game
of baseball.

KATE RILEY: I know that
this part of the year

is all about
pre-season predictions.

I don't know if you're
willing to make a World
Series prediction for us.

But what are your hopes
for the season ahead?

ROB MANFRED: Well, my
most important hope

is that we have the
same kind of storylines

emerge during the course
of the 2017 season

that we had last year, so that
our great local audiences stay

with us through the
postseason, and we

see the kind of
excitement that we saw
during the 2016 World Series.
